awd_titl_txt: Enriching the Undergraduate Experience through Personalized Learning and Mentoring
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, the "Enriching the Undergraduate Experience through Personalized Learning and Mentoring" program will support high-achieving, low-income computer science and engineering students with demonstrated financial at the Missouri University of Science and Technology. This four-year S-STEM Track 2 project will provide scholarships to 21 financially at-risk sophomores, in three cohorts of seven students. The first cohort will be funded for three years; the second cohort will be funded for two years; and the third cohort will be funded for one year.  In addition to the scholarships, students will receive faculty mentoring and participate in community building activities.  They will also receive help in one of their challenging computing courses through a new software program that can deliver personalized learning opportunities.

The objectives of this S-STEM Track 2 project are to a) increase retention and graduation rates of participating students, ideally to 100% within five years; b) attain 100% placement in jobs or graduate programs well-suited to participating students' talents and interests; c) evaluate the activities carried out during the project to identify best practices that can be scaled to larger student cohorts and adapted to other disciplines and institutions. Personalized learning support in the computer engineering and computer science courses will be provided to the scholars using the PERCEPOLIS cyber infrastructure developed by the investigators. Scholars will engage in professional development opportunities that aim to better motivate and prepare them for computer science careers and/or graduate education, with a blended learning approach supported by the PERCEPOLIS software that enables collection of data on learning outcomes and engagement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The “Enriching the Undergraduate Experience through Personalized Learning and Mentoring” program at the Missouri University of Science and Technology aimed to provide scholarships to academically talented students in financial need, retain all Scholars to graduation within five years, attain 100% placement in employment or graduate programs well-suited to the talents and interests of each Scholar, and evaluate and document the activities carried out during the project to identify best practices that can be scaled to larger cohorts and adapted to other disciplines and institutions.

From 2018 to 2024, we provided scholarships of up to $10,000 per year, faculty and peer mentoring, research opportunities, and academic and professional development support to computer engineering (CpE) and computer science (CS) students. A total of $431,000 in scholarships was awarded to 21 unique Scholars in three cohorts.

100% of the Scholars graduated within 4.5 years, with an average cumulative GPA of 3.8 (out of 4.0). 100% were employed or enrolled in a graduate program upon graduating with a BS. 19 Scholars (90%) completed at least one internship or coop during their time in the program. Ten scholars (48%) enrolled in the accelerated master’s degree; six based their master’s theses on research they carried out in the S-STEM program.

Notable achievements by the Scholars include honorable mention, respectively, for the NSF Graduate Research Fellowship Program and IEEE-HKN Alton B. Zerby and Carl T. Koerner Outstanding Student Award; Department of Education Graduate Assistance in Areas of National Need fellowship for PhD study; and NSF Scholarships for Federal Service (SFS) funding for MS study. One refereed book chapter, five refereed conference papers, three refereed journal papers, and two undergraduate honors theses resulted. Four MS theses were completed; another two were in progress as of the closing of the award.

Evaluation of the project concluded that scholars perceived strong mentoring, improved research, interpersonal, and leadership skills, and reduced financial anxiety. The program was found to be instrumental in educating Scholars who are proficient in computing and able to address the urgent national need for a skilled computing workforce.  

 


Last Modified: 03/03/2025
Modified by: Sahra Sedigh Sarvestani
